awd_titl_txt: Low Dimensional Topology and holomorphic disks
awd_abstract_narration:
The award supports the principal investigator's research in topology, a mathematical study of properties of spaces that are preserved under continuous deformations, such as stretching and bending. The central theme in this research is to develop a better understanding of a highly effective mathematical tool known as the knot Floer homology that is used in the study of three- and four-dimensional spaces and knotted loops. The PI and his collaborators have done foundational work in this area. The proposed project builds on their recent success in approaching knot Floer homology and related invariants of three-dimensional spaces by means of algebraic techniques, thereby making them much more tractable. In addition to applications within the abstract field of topology, the methods are closely related to other areas of mathematics that are motivated by physics, such as gauge theory and symplectic geometry. The completion of this project would lead to new bridges between different research areas and methods. The project also includes investigating the relationship between various invariants for knots, and computational problems in knot theory.

Heegaard-Floer homology provides various tools to study problems in low-dimensional topology. The construction, first developed by Peter Ozsvath and the principal investigator, uses methods both from topology and symplectic geometry through the study of Heegaard diagrams, and holomorphic disks in symmetric products of Heegaard surfaces.  There are special families of three-manifolds, including fibered three-manifolds and Dehn surgeries along knots, where advances in knot Floer homology and Heegaard-Floer homology are expected to lead to new topological applications. Related research directions involve concordance invariants, smoothly slice knots and smooth four-manifolds. The project also aims to further develop algebraic constructions to study problems in knot theory, and investigate relationships between different knot homology invariants.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project studies research problems related to embedded circles in the standard three-dimensional Euclidean space. It also studies more complicated topological spaces that can be locally modelled on the standard three space. These three-dimensional manifolds are closely tied with the study of knots through a method called surgery. One of the main topological invariants used in the project is knot Floer homology developed earlier in a joint work of Ozsvath and the PI, and also independently by Rasmussen. The project also uses a corresponding topological invariant called Heegaard Floer homology for three-dimensional manifolds (developed in an earlier joint work of Ozsvath and the PI).

In a joint work with Ozsvath, the PI has further developed a topological invariant for embedded knotted circles in the standard three-dimensional space. This algebraically defined homology theory uses a combinatorial presentation of the knot through general knot projections to a two-dimensional plane. There are variations of this algebraic invariant, the most complex version developed during this project is over  a polynomial algebra generated by two elements over the integers: Z[U,V] and divided with the relation UV = 0.  

During the project the PI together with Ozsvath proved that over mod 2 coefficients, a specialization of the above algebraic knot invariant computes the holomorphically defined "hat"-version of knot Floer homology. Another specialization (working with U = 0) can be identified with the "minus"-version of knot Floer homology. This, together with some earlier work on the algebraic invariant, gives a fast computation of these knot Floer homology theories.This work also leads to a practical computation of other knot invariants, including the Seifert genus of a knot, and give a new way to determine whether a knot K presented by a knot diagram  can be isotoped to the unknot. A related application detects whether a knot K belongs  to a special family of knots called fibered knots.

The PI together with Ozsvath has extended the algebraic constructions to the case of multiple components as well. The project has also extended the earlier symplectic geometric techniques to deal with the link case. As an application this work gives a new way to compute a version of Link Floer homology and related link invariants.

The PI has also studied surgery problems for knots. Dehn surgery along a knot in a three-dimensional space can be used to change the underlying space by cutting out a tube-like neighborhood of the circle and gluing it back differently. This procedure is governed by a rational number, also called the slope of the surgery. In a joint work with Stipsicz, the PI used some recent advances in knot Floer homology and Heegaard Floer homology together with more classical invariants to prove the purely cosmetic surgery conjecture for the family of pretzel knots. This work shows that if K is a knot in this family then  different surgery slopes along K always produce different oriented three-manifolds.


Last Modified: 12/05/2020
Modified by: Zoltan Szabo
